abstract.p: IBM introduces software, snippet of code under 100 lines long, that sharply increases performance of its PowerNP network management microprocessor; software gives processor more flexibility in allocating bandwidth priority on computer networks like the Internet (S)

block.p: I.B.M. has brought out software -- a snippet of code under 100 lines long -- that sharply increases the performance of its PowerNP network management microprocessor. The software gives the processor more flexibility in allocating bandwidth priority on computer networks like the Internet. If it works as planned, network operators could segregate and give priority to functions like live video or important business transactions in periods of peak demand. That could eventually allow Internet service providers to charge higher prices for speedier service, much like the Postal Service and Federal Express.
